title: 108_hr1556
content: The "Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2003" requires publicly traded corporations to make certain tax information available. The "Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2003" mandates specified corporations to electronically file and disclose certain tax information to the public within 30 days of filing their tax return. The Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2003 requires certain corporations to disclose various tax information, including net corporate income tax, Federal income tax expense, taxable income, adjusted book income, and specific differences between taxable income and adjusted book income related to transactions, depreciation, stock options, and consolidated entities. The Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2003 mandates disclosure of tax information for certain corporations, including net corporate income tax, Federal income tax expense, taxable income, adjusted book income, and explanations for differences between taxable income and adjusted book income related to transactions and other specified items. The Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2003 requires disclosure of tax information for specified corporations, accessible electronically by search criteria such as corporation name, headquarters location, taxable year, and CUSIP identification number. The term 'specified corporation' refers to corporations required to register securities under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 or domestic corporations in an affiliated group. For corporations filing a consolidated return, 'specified corporation' applies to the group as a whole. 'Net corporate income tax' is defined as the total regular tax liability and tax. The term 'adjusted book income' refers to book income reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission without certain deductions. The amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. STUDY OF TAX SHELTER ACTIVITY. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study on recent corporate tax shelter activity in coordination with relevant committees. A report with recommendations must be submitted within 1 year. The Secretary of the Treasury will submit a report with recommendations on corporate tax shelter activity, including disclosing additional information from the corporate income tax return. The report will also detail actions taken to implement the recommendations.
